IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
On September 18, 2023, I, Sgt. Angermeier was notified by Washington County CPS of an incoming case of alleged child sex abuse. 

On September 25, 2023 at 0907 hours, CAC Supervisor/ Case Worker Rachel Mazloum conducted a forensic interview with the alleged victim, Sara Stambaugh, 13 YOA. I was present for the interview in the observation room. SAFE Nurse Sammy Saylor was also present. 

BELOW IS A SUMMARY OF THE INTERVIEW. TO SEE WORD FOR WORD OF THE INTERVIEW, PLEASE SEE THE RECORDED INTERVIEW.

Narrative practice was utilized. Child reports she likes to ride horses. When she grows up she would like to be a professional barrel racer. She explained to the case worker what barrel racing was. Child spoke about helping around the horse barn with different chores. Child reports that she doesn’t like school.
Worker inquired about members of her family. Child listed: Grandma (Sandy), Mom (Melissa), Dad (Charles), Little brother (Charlie, 10), Little Sister, Angel (15), Other brother (Zachary, 23). Child reports everybody listed lives in the home. Child reports her grandma is “an old bat” because “she is old”. Mom, Charlie and her play games together. She and Angel play horses together. She and Zach fight. Child reports her and Charlie don’t really play games together anymore because Charlie has a tablet now and is frequently on it. Worker inquired about what her and Zach fight about. She stated “a whole bunch”. Child reports Zach throws shoes at her and they argue. She further reports Zach “hits” her with his hands and fists on her arms. Worker asked about the last time they fought. She said yesterday she had asked him to do something and he just threw a shoe at her. Worker asked what child does at home. Child spoke about riding her bike, playing outside with her chickens, and being in her room listening to music. She reports she listens to music on a speaker connected to Wi-Fi. Child reports she does not have any devices, but does report she uses other people’s phones. Worker inquired about what she looks at on those devices. Child stated “I don’t want to [tell you about it].”
An open invitation was provided. Worker asked if the child knew why she was here today, or if anybody told her why she came in today. Child denied both.
Body safety was introduced. Worker asked the child about touches she does like. Child stated “nothing”. Worker inquired if there were any touches that made the child uncomfortable. Child stated “I want to leave…so I can go to school.”
Worker reentered the room. She inquired if anybody comes into their home beside their family. She reports she has two uncles, an aunt and a cousin who come into the home. She also reported a family friend, Donald, comes over. One aunt and uncle, and her cousin, do not visit as they used to because they moved to Hancock. Worker inquired about Donald. Child stated “I don’t want to talk about it.” Worker reiterated her safety in the room. Child was unable to provide any details about Donald such as: how long he has been their friend or how old he is. Child had a visible change in body language and asked how much longer this was going to take. Child reports Donald has a shop in Hancock that she used to help him at. She reports she no longer does, but Angel does, because Donald doesn’t want her down there anymore. Child was unsure of the details of why she can’t be there. Worker inquired what she does when she uses her friend’s cell phones. Worker asked if there was ever anything on the cell phone that made her uncomfortable; she stated no. Worker asked if anybody ever asked her to do something on a phone that made her uncomfortable; She stated she didn’t want to talk about it, but did not clarify what it was. The interview was ended after returning to a neutral topic.

Due to Sara not disclosing a crime and refusing to answer CW Mazloums questions, this case is closed as unfounded.

All events occurred in Washington County, MD.
